subject: Re: Conditionally running tests
msgSnippet: My plan for desktop running was to have a seperate IDEA run configuration that sets the system parameter, so developers can always pick which one to run.
messageBody:
My plan for desktop running was to have a seperate IDEA run
configuration that sets the system parameter, so developers can always
pick which one to run.

Regarding using a custom runner, I'm not sure how your suggestion
differs from what I am doing. I suppose we could start looking at a
custom Request object that returns a runner that is never intended to
be used with the @RunWith annotation, but rather delegates run
building on each class. But I'm not sure that IDEA or ant support a
custom Request object, or how you would get them to use it.

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Malte Finsterwalder <malte@...> wrote:
>
> yme0987654321 wrote:
> > In answer to your second question, basically the slow tests would run
> > at check in, or during the general build process, whereas the fast
> > test would just be part of the TDD of making sure everything is green.
> > For point of comparison, the slow tests are currently 1/2 hour for
> > less than 100, and the fast tests are under 60 seconds, even though
> > there are about 700 of them.
>
> I understand that reasoning.
>
> But as you said you want to have several categories:
> DB-Tests, In Container Tests, ...
> Maybe you should create a runner hat can be parameterized to handle all
> these cases?
>
> And how do you setup the runtime, so that it does run the tests or does
> not run the tests on a per run basis?
> Setting a system property seams cumbersome to me.
> That's ok for the server, but sometimes I want to run the slow tests on
> my desktop too, don't I?
>
> Maybe we can come up with something better?
>
> Greetings,
> Malte
>
